snippet: Russian aircraft carried out a bombing attack against Syrian opposition fighters, including at least one group trained by the C.I.A., eliciting angry protests from American officials.
abstract: Russian warplanes strike Syrian opposition groups, including at least one group trained by CIA, drawing condemnation from American officials; Pres Vladimir Putin claims Russia aims to combat Islamic State fighters, but American authorities say attacks are directed not at ISIS but at other opposition groups fighting Pres Bashar al-Assad; critics warn attack brings new instability to region and diminishes prospect of peaceful resolution.

byline.original: By HELENE COOPER, MICHAEL R. GORDON and NEIL MacFARQUHAR
byline.contributor: Helene Cooper reported from Washington, Michael R. Gordon from New York, and Neil MacFarquhar from Moscow. Eric Schmitt contributed reporting from Washington, Somini Sengupta from the United Nations, and Anne Barnard from Beirut, Lebanon.

lead_paragraph: Russian aircraft carried out a bombing attack against Syrian opposition fighters, including at least one group trained by the C.I.A., eliciting angry protests from American officials.

headline.main: Russians Strike Targets in Syria, but Not ISIS Areas
headline.print_headline: Russians Strike Targets in Syria, but Not ISIS Areas

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
